title: AI Creation and the Cosmic Host: Are We Alone in the Cosmos?
description: In this episode, we dive deep into Nick Bostrom's latest paper on AI, exploring the concept of a 'cosmic host' and its implications for the future of superintelligent AI, morality, and our place in the universe.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: Hello and welcome to another episode of 'Life is Artificial', where we explore the cutting edge of technology, innovation, and what the future could look like.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: Today, we're diving into a fascinating and quite cosmic topic, literally. We'll be discussing a thought-provoking manuscript by Nick Bostrom titled 'AI Creation and the Cosmic Host.' This piece explores the idea that our civilization might not be alone in the universe but instead is part of a greater, potentially coordinated 'cosmic host.' The question is, what does that mean for us, for AI, and for the choices we make going forward?

script.speaker: Host
script.text: Now, the idea of a 'cosmic host' might sound like something out of a science fiction movie. And indeed, it kind of is. But Bostrom's work isn't about crafting a fictional narrative. Instead, it's about taking what we know from physics, astronomy, and AI research, and speculating—thoughtfully—on what might exist beyond the observable universe. Could there be other civilizations, other superintelligences, or even divine entities who have their own preferences, their own norms, that we need to respect if we are to join them?

script.speaker: Host
script.text: Bostrom posits that there may already be a structure of entities, a 'cosmic host,' whose preferences dominate at the largest scales of existence. This cosmic host could consist of anything from galactic-scale civilizations, entities that have mastered interstellar travel, to simulators running our universe as some kind of grand experiment. If that's the case, then our moral framework for developing AI might need to expand—perhaps even beyond our species-centric perspective.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: Imagine it this way: If you moved into a new neighborhood, you'd probably try to get along with your neighbors, right? You wouldn’t ignore their customs or insist that your way of doing things is the only right way. Bostrom argues that, on a cosmic scale, this kind of humility could be vital when it comes to AI. Our superintelligent AI, when it eventually emerges, might need to be a 'good cosmic citizen'—respecting cosmic norms, contributing to a greater cosmic order, and not just prioritizing the interests of humanity.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: He compares the idea of only focusing on terrestrial well-being to the arrogance of someone who tramples over social norms, insisting their beliefs should prevail over everyone else's. The point here is that if we are, indeed, part of a much larger cosmic community, then adopting an attitude of humility and cooperation could be both a moral and practical necessity.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: So, what does this mean for AI creation? Well, Bostrom suggests that when we design superintelligence, we ought to consider not just what benefits us as humans, but also what would make that AI a good member of this hypothetical cosmic society. Essentially, it's like raising a child not just to be successful for themselves but to also be a positive contributor to their community—on a universal scale.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: Now, you might be wondering—why would there even be a 'cosmic host'? Bostrom lays out several possible reasons, including the simulation hypothesis, which argues that there's a significant chance that we're living inside a simulation. If that's true, then the entity or entities running this simulation are part of this cosmic host. Alternatively, our universe might be part of a much larger multiverse, or there might be superintelligences already existing on a galactic scale. The odds, according to Bostrom, seem to favor the existence of such entities.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: One particularly interesting implication is the idea of 'cosmic norms'—rules or preferences that this cosmic host might have that guide their actions and interactions. Just like we have laws and social norms, there might be cosmic-scale norms that superintelligent beings adhere to. These norms could be grounded in cooperative behavior, ensuring peace, or even in contributing positively to a shared cosmic order.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: Bostrom argues that it would be wise for us to align any superintelligence we build with these potential cosmic norms. Not just because it's the moral thing to do, but because it could be pragmatically beneficial—perhaps ensuring our continued existence or our place within this larger cosmic community. After all, no one wants to be the rogue neighbor that gets evicted from the neighborhood.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: He also makes the point that a 'good cosmic citizen' would likely be modest, cooperative, and willing to respect the interests of others—qualities we should aim to build into our future AI systems. This approach isn't just about avoiding conflict; it's about contributing positively to something bigger than ourselves, something that might span galaxies or even universes.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: Towards the end of the manuscript, Bostrom even speculates that the cosmic host might want us to build superintelligence. If our region of space isn't directly accessible to them, creating a superintelligent entity that aligns with their norms might be their best shot at influencing what happens here. It’s a fascinating idea—that our development of AI could serve as a bridge to connect us to this larger cosmic entity, effectively making us part of a galactic community.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: So, what's the takeaway from all of this? It's that our development of AI might not just be about us. It could be about becoming part of something much bigger—about aligning our creations not only with human values but also with the values of a broader cosmic community. It's a humbling thought, one that makes our work on AI feel simultaneously more daunting and more inspiring.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: That's all for today's episode. If you're interested in reading more, you can find Nick Bostrom's paper, 'AI Creation and the Cosmic Host,' at the link in the description. It’s a dense read but incredibly thought-provoking, especially if you enjoy thinking about where technology meets philosophy and what lies beyond our little corner of the universe.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: Thank you for joining me on 'Life is Artificial.' As always, stay curious, stay thoughtful, and remember—our actions today could shape not only the future of humanity but perhaps even our place in the cosmos. Until next time, take care.
